Learn More & Join Download Assignment PDF Before You Shoot â€¢ Gather your macro or zoom lens and ensure it is clean and ready for use. â€¢ Set up your tripod in a stable location to minimize camera shake. â€¢ Choose a shooting location with good natural light or prepare to use artificial light sources. â€¢ Decide on your subject matter, such as flowers, insects, or textures. â€¢ Set your camera to aperture priority mode with a fixed ISO of 200. The Assignment Technical Focus â€¢ Utilize aperture priority mode to control depth of field effectively. â€¢ Experiment with different focal lengths to discover optimal working distances. â€¢ Use a remote shutter release or timer to prevent camera shake. â€¢ Incorporate focus stacking techniques to achieve greater depth of field. â€¢ Adjust your lighting setup to minimize harsh shadows and highlight textures. Creative Focus â€¢ Explore negative space in your compositions to draw attention to your subject. â€¢ Try varying your angles and distances to create unique perspectives. â€¢ Incorporate natural elements or props to add context to your macro shots. â€¢ Experiment with backlighting to enhance the details and colors of your subject. â€¢ Use shallow depth of field to isolate your subject and create a dreamy effect. Assignment Tasks â€¢ Capture a close-up shot of a flower's petals using aperture priority mode at f/4, allowing the camera to adjust shutter speed for optimal exposure. â€¢ Photograph an insect resting on a leaf, using aperture priority mode at f/5.6 to achieve sharp details while blurring the background. â€¢ Create a macro image of a textured surface (like bark or stone), using aperture priority mode at f/8 to enhance depth of field and detail. â€¢ Shoot a close-up of a water droplet on a leaf, utilizing aperture priority mode at f/2.8 to emphasize the droplet against a blurred background. â€¢ Take a series of three images of the same subject with varying focus points to practice focus stacking techniques. â€¢ Experiment with artificial lighting by photographing a small object with a flashlight or LED panel, using aperture priority mode at f/4. ðŸ’¡ Stretch Tasks â€¢ Create a composite image using focus stacking techniques, combining multiple photos taken at different focus points for maximum sharpness. â€¢ Experiment with macro photography at night, using a tripod and artificial light sources to capture nocturnal subjects.
